title: AmaizingEnzymes
fulltitle: Leaf enzyme activities and total proteins of maize hybrids cultivated in the field
description: Enzymatic activities (phosphoglucose isomerase, triosephosphate isomerase,glutamine synthetase, glutamate dehydrogenase, alanine aminotransferase, aspartate aminotransferase) and total proteins of young leaves of maize plants cultivated in the field with normal or early sowing in 2013 and 2014, and with two nitrogen nutrition levels in 2014. Analyses performed on the genetic diversity of a core panel of 30 European hybrids and commercial hybrids in AMAIZING ANR project.
publication_citation: Urrutia, M., Blein-Nicolas, M., Fernandez, O., Bernillon, S., Maucourt, M., Deborde, C., ... & Moing, A. (2023). Identification of metabolic and protein markers representative of the impact of mild nitrogen deficit on agronomic performance of maize hybrids
subject: Agricultural Sciences

title: AmaizingNMR
fulltitle: NMR metabolomic and starch data of young leaf of maize hybrids cultivated in the field with normal sowing in 2013
description: Metabolomic and starch analyses of young leaves of maize plants cultivated in the field with normal sowing in 2013. Analyses performed on the genetic diversity of a core panel of 30 European hybrids and a commercial hybrid in AMAIZING ANR project (https://amaizing.fr/). Proton NMR analyses of leaf extracts. Starch analyses of pellets.
publication_citation: Lamari, N., Zhendre, V., Urrutia, M., Bernillon, S., Maucourt, M., Deborde, C., Prodhomme, D., Jacob, D., Ballias, P., Rolin, D., Sellier, H., Rabier, D., Gibon, Y., Giauffret, C., Moing, A. (2018). Metabotyping of 30 maize hybrids under early-sowing conditions reveals potential marker-metabolites for breeding. Metabolomics, 14(10), 132.
subject: Agricultural Sciences

resources.description: Dataset in the INRAE Data repository

title: Atacama
description: Predictive metabolomics performed on 24 extremophile plant species in 19 different sites along an elevation transect in the Atacama Desert. (2021-06-01)
publication_citation: Thomas Dussarrat, Sylvain Prigent, Claudio Latorre, Stéphane Bernillon, Amélie Flandin, Francisca P Díaz, Cédric Cassan, Pierre Van Delft, Daniel Jacob, Kranthi Varala , Jérôme Joubes, Yves Gibon, Dominique Rolin, Rodrigo A Gutiérrez, Pierre Pétriacq (2022) Predictive metabolomics of multiple Atacama plant species unveils a core set of generic metabolites for extreme climate resilience. New Phytologis
subject: Earth and Environmental Sciences

title: frim1
description: The project aimed to build a virtual tomato fruit that enables the prediction of metabolite levels given genetic and environmental inputs, by an iterative process between laboratories which combine expertise in fruit biology, ecophysiology, theoretical and experimental biochemistry, and biotechnology.
publication_citation: Biais B, Bénard C, Beauvoit B, Colombié S, Prodhomme D, Ménard G, Bernillon S, Gehl B, Gautier H, Ballias P, Mazat J-P, Sweetlove L, Génard M, Gibon Y. 2014. Remarkable reproducibility of enzyme activity profiles in tomato fruits grown under contrasting environments provides a roadmap for studies of fruit metabolism. Plant Physiology 164, 1204-1221
subject: Computer and Information Science
Medicine Health and Life Sciences

resources.description: Bénard et al (2015) Journal of Experimental Botany Vol. 66, No. 11 pp. 3391–3404
Access to data via cloud-like software

title: Frimouss
fulltitle: FRuit Integrative MOdelling for a Unified Selection System
description: Fruit production is affected by environmental hazards, but also by changes in consumer demand in terms of taste or nutritional value, resulting in a constant need to change varieties and / or cultivation practices. A key objective is therefore to understand the factors that influence the growth and quality of fruits, so that they can be used to improve the desired traits. Metabolism, the motor of living matter, is an obvious target for the improvement of cultivated plants, especially in fruits whose metabolic composition strongly influences quality. FRIMOUSS makes the bet that the comparison of species will help to better understand the link between programming of metabolism, growth and quality of the fruits, which will make it possible to identify essential points of regulation, in particular in terms of trade-offs between metabolic and biophysical components that determine the quality of the fruit.
publication_citation: Léa Roch, Sylvain Prigent, Holger Klose, Coffi-Belmys Cakpo, Bertrand Beauvoit, et al.. Biomass composition explains fruit relative growth rate and discriminates climacteric from non-climacteric species. Journal of Experimental Botany, Oxford University Press (OUP), 2020, 71 (19), pp.5823-5836
subject: Agricultural Sciences

resources.description: Journal of Experimental Botany, Oxford University Press, 2020
Growth modeling applied to several fruit species

title: Frimouss-PeppEgg
fulltitle: 1H-NMR metabolomic profiling data of eggplant or pepper fruit during its development
description: Metabolomic analyses of eggplant and pepper fruits cultivated in a greenhouse: Quantitative 1H-NMR profiling of fruit extracts at 11 or 10 stages of development
publication_citation: In preparation : Metabolite quantification data based on 1H-NMR profiling of eggplant or pepper fruit during its development. Léa Roch, Catherine Deborde, Daniel Jacob, Anaïs Clave, Marguerite Batsale, Yves Gibon, Annick Moing
subject: Agricultural Sciences

title: Metabofla1
fulltitle: Infection response and susceptibility reduction in the pathosystem Grapevine / Flavescence dorée
description: The objective of this project is to determine which primary and secondary or specialized metabolites are disrupted in grapevines following Flavescence dorée infection under controlled conditions. The metabolites investigated include sugars, amino acids, organic acids and phenolic compounds (such as stilbenes, involved in the response to pathogens). Comparison between healthy and infected plants on the one hand, and between CS and M on the other hand, will allow the identification of metabolites or pathways that are associated with better resistance to FD. Additional experimentation on a less susceptible sibling of M (MagCF10) will be an asset for this comparison.
note: Funding information: FED Bordeaux University « Projets Emergents » MetaboFla
subject: Agricultural Sciences

title: NMRmetoboRing
fulltitle: NMR metabolite quantification of a synthetic urine sample: an inter-laboratory comparison of processing workflows
description: Inter-laboratory tests for metabolite quantification of a synthetic urine using 1H-NMR. Comparison of zgpr and NOESY-pr experiments and of several spectra processing strategies for metabolite quantification.
publication_citation: Cécile Canlet, Catherine Deborde, Edern Cahoreau, Grégory Da Costa, Roselyne Gautier, Daniel Jacob, Cyril Jousse, Mélia Lacaze, Inès le Mao, Estelle Martineau, Lindsay Peyriga, Tristan Richard, Virginie Silvestre, Mounir Traïkia, Annick Moing, Patrick Giraudeau (2023) NMR metabolite quantification of a synthetic urine sample: an inter-laboratory comparison of processing workflows, Metabolomics journal doi: 10.1007/s11306-023-02028-4
subject: Medicine Health and Life Sciences

resources.description: NMR spectra along with the quantification

title: untwist1
description: Climatic variability and extreme weather events are increasingly impacting crop yield and value. UNTWIST addresses this challenge and will take advantage of the climate-resilient, traditional European oilseed crop camelina to provide a mechanistic understanding of successful adaptation strategies to drought and heat stress. Moreover, it will develop predictive models and robust markers for crop performance for variable environments. UNTWIST´s long term aim is to improve crop resilience and yield stability in changing, challenging climates; its legacy will contribute towards increasing the sustainability of European agriculture.
subject: Agricultural Sciences
